noun.description: A piece of cloth or other material used to mend or strengthen a torn or weak point.
A part of something marked out from the rest by a particular characteristic.
examples: his hair was combed forward to hide a growing bald patch

noun.description: A small piece of ground, especially one used for gardening.
examples: they spent Sundays digging their vegetable patch

noun.description: A period of time seen as a distinct unit with a characteristic quality.
examples: he may have been going through a bad patch

noun.description: A temporary electrical or telephone connection.
A small piece of code inserted into a program to improve its functioning or to correct an error.

verb.description: Mend or strengthen (fabric or an item of clothing) by putting a piece of material over a hole or weak point in it.
Treat someone's injuries or repair the damage to something, especially hastily.
examples: they did their best to patch up the gaping wounds

verb.description: Connect by a temporary electrical, radio, or telephonic connection.
examples: Ralph had patched her through to the meeting by walkie-talkie

verb.description: Correct, enhance, or modify (a routine or program) by inserting a patch.

phrases: he no longer looked so handsomeâ€”he wasn't a patch on Peter
Even as she lay beside him, Erin couldn't help but notice his lean body wasn't a patch on Cade's hard-muscled form.
It IS indeed very cold at the moment, but I think not a patch on the ice storms mentioned in previous weeks by our friends on the US East Coast.
It's not a patch on what I have at the moment, but perhaps it'll grow on me.
The line-up of performers is - in theory at least - not too bad, although it's definitely not a patch on the original line-up.
origin: Late Middle English: perhaps from a variant of Old French pieche, dialect variant of piece piece.
